conclusion: Understanding the problem involves an x-t graph depicting vehicle performance.
Graph has axes labeled x/t in meters per second on the y-axis and t in seconds on the x-axis with a solid line from t=-2 to t=0 and a dashed line continuing.
The graph shows how the ratio of position to time changes with time.
The problem asks for the car's speed at the end of the 2nd second.
Speed is the magnitude of velocity, which is the derivative of position with respect to time.
Need to relate x/t graph to velocity or speed.
x/t is like average velocity, not instantaneous velocity.
Need instantaneous speed at t=2 seconds, possibly by finding the slope of the x-t graph.
Rearranging x = (x/t) * t doesn't seem immediately helpful.
Solid line from t=-2 to t=0, dashed line continues, point at (0,10) on y-axis.
At t=0, x/t = 10 m/s, meaning x = 10 meters at t=0.
At t=-2 seconds, x/t is 0, meaning x=0 meters at t=-2 seconds.
From t=-2 to t=0, position increases from 0 to 10 meters.
From t=0 to t=2 seconds, position continues to increase based on the dashed line.
Find an expression for x in terms of t.
Slope of x versus t from t=-2 to t=0 is 5 m/s.
Consider x/t as a function of t, x(t) = [x/t(t)] * t.
Differentiate x(t) to find dx/dt.
Express x/t in terms of t and find dx/dt.
x/t increases linearly from 0 to 10 m/s between t=-2 and t=0.
x/t(t) = m*t + c, with m = 5 m/sÂ².
